narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Best readings of my life.

Q.7: This course has helped me to re-think many of the management frameworks i knew before Yale for addressing conservation and development problems. The Professor through his critical and thought-provoking weekly analyzes of varied topics, has helped me view environmental problems/solutions from a much more critical angle.

This course was useful to MFers as a way to think about forestry in a new light. This class helps students develop the skills to not as why something is happening but why are we asking this question of the situation. It helps the students take a step back.
the readings

Professor Dove draws on a years of accumulated wisdom in a multitude of fields. His insight on framing large issues and applications to contemporary events and problems are fascinating. This course forced me to become a better thinker and researcher which is useful even if I will not become an academic.
The group-lead discussions sessions
the amount of writing and analytical skill set acquired in the course.
The way our class discussions stemmed from the course readings. Interesting persepectives from different classmates was very beneficial.

The format worked well (beginning with a lecture and then moving into a peer-facilitated discussion section). I think this format helped to push people to pay closer attention to the readings than they would have otherwise.
The paper and the readings

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Michael needs to make the leap to powerpoint, and give a standing lecture

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: exellent and quite available
Both the instructor and the TA made themselves available to discuss key course concepts and any related topics.

The Professor and the TA were available throughout the life of the course. I contacted the TA for some clarifications about "paper topic(s)" and writing. I also attended a session that dealt with a review of the different readings assigned during the life of the course.The Professor always provided ready and helpful responses whenever i contacted him.
Both the instructor and the TA were very responsive and gave constructive advice.
Help was always available.
They were both very helpful in offering advice. I really appreciated how Lauren organized so many events for the class, like the paper-writing workshop, etc.
TA was very available but the instructor was harder to get time with, although he always did make time at some point.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This course is essential for anyone hoping to explore social ecology as either a practitioner or a researcher. The history and theory of natural resource use and debates can inform any topic of inquiry.
It does fit into my overall program in the sense that it fulfills my desire to learn about how environmental and developmental problems/solutions are framed and addressed.
I wish to focus my work on social ecology so this course was very pertinent.

My overall course of study here involves both the social sciences and natural sciences. I plan to work with communities and help them to access natural resources and build positive connections with the natural world.
Helps me think about forestry and forest management in a new way. Taking a step back and asking why are we concerned about this or that, instead of blindly doing this or that.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To gain a foundation in social ecology theory
To learn more about how environmental and development problems are framed and addressed
My career will involve working with communities, not just natural resources... therefore it is important to understand socially-constructed realities.
Needed a class.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: exceeded.
Surpassed them.
Yes it did!
yes.

Yes, although my personal career will probably be more domestically focused, while most of the case studies of this course involved "development" work abroad, there were still plenty of relevant and transferable lessons.
This class blew me away. I the concepts in this class make a lot of sense to me.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: I took away much more from this course than I had expected.
Yes, see above.
and more.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The group work made our discussions in class much more lively and informative.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be prepared to spend a lot of time preparing for each week. The more you put in the more you get out. The readings and discussion are relevant to a wide range of topics. Lead discussions on weeks where the topics are of most interest to you, because it takes quite a while to prepare for discussion and you will reap the strongest benefits from the sections you lead.Give yourself time to digest. The course starts by establishing a framework for critical thinking that you may be challenging to appreciate all at once.
Go for it and come prepared to have some of the "business-as-usual" models in conservation and development work questioned.
Start your term paper early! Cannot stress this enough.

At first you might find it frustrating if you are accustomed to producing "solutions"... this course is not really about that... the point of it is to take a step back and re-examine assumptions. As a result there will be more "problems" than "solutions." The goal of this class is to examine the unexamined... If you stick with it you will find that this is a very valuable practice.
Be prepared for a lot of reading. The readings are long but move quickly. Not all students will be equally prepared for the class discussions, it is very apparent, do the reading.
